awd_titl_txt: Spatial Variation and the Origins of Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Natalie Munro of the University of Connecticut will provide a local scale investigation of the transition to agriculture, while addressing contentious debates over long-term subsistence evolution, the emergence of settled life, and the process of plant and animal domestication. The origins to agriculture had a profound impact on all aspects of human sociocultural life. Although research once emphasized single origins of agricultural products, accumulating data increasingly support multiregional models that emphasize local scale processes in the emergence and adoption of agriculture. This project will take an essential next step: the creation of a high-resolution, local-scale reconstruction of the transition to agriculture and the process of plant and animal domestication. Detailed reconstructions of local-scale forager-farmer transition are few, but are necessary to map study how ideas, plants and animals were innovated and transferred across much larger time scales and geographic areas. Although the forager-farmer transition is most often viewed dichotomously as an adoption versus an in situ scenario, Dr. Munro and colleagues will consider information exchange and the movement of plants and animals among localities in Southwest Asia via interaction networks. The project will provide student training and education, foster international collaboration and engage in public outreach. Results will be disseminated to public audiences through a museum exhibit, articles for public audiences, and a series of lectures. 

This study will contribute to the study of agricultural origins by providing, a high-resolution dataset for the Upper Jordan Valley (UJV) of Israel. The UJV provides an especially interesting test case because of its unique ecological conditions created by a large fresh-water system, its low elevation and the accessibility of trade routes through the larger Rift Valley. These conditions also allow investigation of more specific socioeconomic questions about topics such as aquatic resource exploitation and the impact of climatic events like the Younger Dryas. Investigation will center on three Epipaleolithic and Pre-Pottery Neolithic sites in the UJV. These include Jordan River Dureijat and Nahal Ein Gev II which together will provide the first complete Epipaleolithic sequence for the UJV, and the Pre-Pottery Neolithic site of Munhatta. More specifically activities will include: (1) test excavations and sampling at Munhatta. Micromorphological, sediment, isotope and zooarchaeological sampling at this critical site will investigate animal keeping, animal mobility, animal exchange and the importance of cereal grasses; (2) the collection of a comprehensive zooarchaeological database from published Epipaleolithic and Pre-Pottery Neolithic sites from the Upper Jordan Valley and more broadly across Southwest Asia to enable a comparative meta-analysis of regional plant and animal domestication pathways, and document the range of methods and measures used to detect the process of animal and plant domestication in adjacent regions; and (3) the collection of zooarchaeological data from Jordan River Dureijat and Nahal Ein Gev II.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Natalie Munro of the University of Connecticut investigated long-term change in human diets and the conditions leading to the first agriculture societies and the emergence of settled life in the Upper Jordan River Valley of Southwest Asia. The emergence to agricultural societies had a profound impact on all aspects of human sociocultural life. Research increasingly indicates the importance of local-scale decision-making in the emergence and adoption of agriculture in Southwest Asia. This study contributed to this larger picture by providing one essential building block, a high-resolution dataset for the Upper Jordan Valley. Together, the Epipaleolithic sites of Jordan River Dureijat and Nahal Ein Gev II provide a multidimensional view of the 10,000 year period leading up to the beginning of the Neolithic (11,500 years ago). The ecological and social conditions are reconstructed using the remains of animals that were hunted and fished by humans. This regionmakes an especially interesting test case because of its unique ecological conditions produced by a large fresh-water system, low elevations and the accessibility of trade routes through the larger Rift Valley.

This project evaluated data collected from the bones of animals used by the residents of these sites to reconstruct the ecological background from which agriculture arose in this region. Using the faunal remains from the large settlement of Nahal Ein Gev II (12,000 years ago) as a launching pad, we compared local population dynamics among Natufian sites in the Jordan Valley with those in the adjacent Mediterranean Hills. Our results showed that late in the Epipaleolithic just before agriculture emerges, human populations were more sedentary in the Jordan Valley which may have provided greater seasonal stability and better access to resources that become increasingly important in succeeding Neolithic periods. Permanent year-round water courses and warmer temperatures may have smoothed out seasonal variability in this region, reducing risk and ultimately supporting larger local populations than in the Neolithic periods that followed.

This project contributes to a more comprehensive picture of Epipaleolithic fishing and waterfowling including the organization of foraging excursions in the Upper Jordan Valley, the development of the local fishery and the role of aquatic resources in the bigger picture of subsistence change for in Southwest Asia. The fauna from Nahal Ein Gev II showed that fisher/hunters used specialized strategies to exploit aquatic resources. The local resients were highly selective of the aquatic resources they captured and transported home. They nearly exclusively chose the largest bodied species of fish and waterfowl and processed their carcasses to maximize the quality of the meat that they transported to the site. When combined with evidence from other material remains from Nahal Ein Gev II and other sites, the results suggest that targeted aquatic resource exploitation is only one of several specialized activities practiced at Nahal Ein Gev II. The residents of the site were engaging in a wide range of specialized activities that required significant knowledge and experience and foreshadowed the emergence of a more complex division of labor in the succeeding Neolithic.

Increased site permanence and territoriality were instrumental ingredients in agricultural origins and significantly impacted the balance between human population size and local environments. Zooarchaeological and chemical isotope analysis of gazelle teeth from Nahal Ein Gev II indicate increased occupation and territoriality in the Upper Jordan Valley at this time. Our results show that hunted gazelles grew up in low topographies where suitable graze was abundant. Gazelle hunting was limited to outcrops below 300 m above modern sea level, within walking distance from the site. Roe deer hunting also took place in riparian thickets along the local stream below the basalt topography that characterizes higher elevations. Our results point to highly localized hunting pattern in the immediate proximity of the site. Although many have hypothesized that increased territoriality was a critical ingredient in the beginning of agriculture in this region, this is the first clear data to definitely support this hypothesis.

This study provided strong primary evidence that populations moved into the upper Jordan Valley in the very Late Epipaleolithic that sedentism was more pronounced than in the adjacent Mediterranean Hills and that residents were exploiting diverse resources within small territories. Aquatic exploitation shows evidence for specialized resource extraction that foreshadows a more explicit division of labor in later periods. These lines of evidence show that allof the pieces were already in place for the emergence of plant and animal domestication and new permanent communities in the Upper Jordan Valley prior to the Neolithic period.

The project provided graduate and undergraduate student training and education and culminated in two international faculty exchanges of the Nahal Ein Gev II (Leore Grosman) and Jordan River Dureijat site directors (Gonen Sharon) at the University of Connecticut.  Results have been disseminated to public audiences through articles for public audiences, and a series of lectures.
